question: 2 (a)
sols_html:
When we look at this series, all its terms are positive, and they are clearly decreasing

\[\begin{aligned} e^{-\sqrt{k}}\end{aligned}\]

is getting smaller and smaller, as is \(1/\sqrt{k}\).

The integral test can be applied here. We know that

\[\begin{aligned} \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{\sqrt{k}} e^{-\sqrt{k}} \text{ converges if and only if } I = \int_1^\infty \frac{1}{\sqrt{x}} e^{-\sqrt{x}} dx \text{ converges.}\end{aligned}\]

The integral I is improper (the infinite range of integration), but it can be evaluated with substitution. Set \(u = \sqrt{x}\) then \(du = \frac{1}{2 \sqrt{x}} dx\), and therefore \(\frac{1}{\sqrt{x}} e^{-\sqrt{x}} dx = 2 e^{-u} du\).

\[\begin{aligned} I = \lim_{R \rightarrow \infty} \int_1^R \frac{1}{\sqrt{x}} e^{-\sqrt{x}} dx = \lim_{R \rightarrow \infty} \int_1^R 2 e^{-u} du = \lim_{R \rightarrow \infty} -2 e^{-u}|_1^R = 2e^{-1}\end{aligned}\]

From the above computation, I converges, and so does the original series.
